newsitem.title: USA: Moody's cites Minn. county investment policies.
newsitem.headline: Moody's cites Minn. county investment policies.

text.p: Investment practices by Hennepin County, Minn., pose some credit risk, but they are offset by the county's underlying credit strengths, according to a report by Moody's Investors Service in its Credit Perspectives publication.

The rating agency said the county relies on the purchase of relatively longer-term investments and uses reverse repurchase agreements to avoid liquidating those investments "should the market fluctuate and interest rates rise."

"This strategy exposes the county's portfolio to greater risk than would a portfolio that contains high-quality, short-term money market instruments whose maturities correspond to liquidity needs," Moody's said.
Steve Bocamozo, a vice president and senior credit officer at Moody's, said Hennepin County's investment strategy is not typical for a municipal government.

However, he said the triple-A rated county has underlying credit strengths, such as substantial balances, flexible revenue raising capability and a strong economy, that alleviate concerns about the county's ability to absorb potential investment losses.
